results.title: Let's look at railways
results.creator_credit: Joan Boundy and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: This film outlines the importance of railways to Australia. It shows the Australian railway system as an important means of transport for primary products, mail and people; traces the history of rail transport from the time of the Industrial Revolution; the effect of introducing railway transport in Australia; the break of gauge problems; the development of powerful locomotives in various states to cope with modern heavy haulages; the future of railways in Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joan Boundy and Australian National Film Board

results.title: The Fire brigade
results.creator_credit: Joan Boundy and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The story of training a young recruit in every aspect of his duty as a fireman attached to a large metropolitan fire brigade. Equipment is demonstrated in detail, including its actual use in a spectacular city fire.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joan Boundy and Australian National Film Board

results.title: Farewell to charms
results.creator_credit: Carla Pontiac, Carole Sklan and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: An experimental feminist film which questions the goals of love and romance as a woman’s ultimate fulfillment. Emma, vivacious but suicidal terrorist is reunited with Cecily, her old school chum. They meet a ‘bionic bike dyke’ called stretch and break open the jelly beans. Will they stretch a point over the pool table? Will tap-dancing and vaginal exercises be enough for Cecily? Will Emma metamorphose into Esther Williams? True romance. Cast includes Radda Jordan, Helen Pankhurst.

results.title: Anzac
results.creator_credit: Jennie Blackwood, Adrian Boddington and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description: Historical photographs and early newsreels tell the story of the Gallipoli assault; embarkation and transport of 75,000 men in 200 ships from Egypt to Gallipoli; initial landing below cliffs; building a jetty and digging in; main British attack at Cape Helles and subsequent assaults on the heights; hardships, casualties and final evacuation. Commentary by Moray Powell and Peter Carver.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jennie Blackwood, Adrian Boddington and Zanthus Films

results.title: Fire of the land (A) [Widescreen]
results.brief_description: This beautifully written, produced and directed documentary by AFTRS student Valerie Bichard encapsulates the emotions and determination of a group of Aboriginal Australians seeking peace and justice in their campaign for Sovereign Rights. Isabell Coe of the Wiradjuri Nation in Central New South Wales, journeyed to the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in Canberra just prior to the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games to collect ashes from the Sacred Fire in order to establish another Tent Embassy with these “healing” ashes in Victoria Park, Sydney. This is the story of Isabell’s peace campaign and the Tent Embassy in Sydney, the frustrations, negotiations, mediations and finally reconciliation with the South Sydney Council and the New South Wales Police. Through Isabell and other Aboriginal Australians including Kevin Buzzcott (Arabunna Nation Elder) and Chicka Dixon (Yuin Nation Elder) along with many of the Embassy supporters, an insight is given to the history of Aboriginal land rights, the birth of the Tent Embassy and the symbolic role which the Tent Embassy plays in promoting understanding between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. Also provides an appreciation and meaning of the importance of the Fire ceremony or “Healing” ceremony towards the act of reconciliation and how such ceremonies are part of Aboriginal culture and their spiritual attachment to the land.
